body:
Hello @ketan,
How are you currently doing on this issue ? I would like to help implement it as well and wanted to ask if you are actively working on it or not so that I won't be stepping on your toes. Please inform me and thanks in advance.
I have not started on this, since I did not receive any confirmation if this might be something the core team would accept.
Well, I believe the issue being tagged indicates that they are interested.

> Well, I believe the issue being tagged indicates that they are interested.

I'm sorry, I did not receive any notification about this. I'm happy to submit a PR. Will likely happen later next week, though.
@haruntuncay if by any chance you have frontend skills (unlike me) could you have a look at https://github.com/joel-costigliola/assertj-core/issues/1485 ? No problem if you can't/don't.
@joel-costigliola Unfortunately I can't say I have frontend skills. By the way, I was working on #1238 if that's okay ?
It would be great if there were also some assertions around file size. e.g. hasAtLeastSize() asAtMostSize().

@ketan are you still interested in contributing more file assertions ?
In that case I would prefer to have one PR per assertion as big PRs take too much time to review.
@tarioch sure, do you have a concrete example ? how would the expected size be expressed ?

I would probably keep it simple and keep size as an long in bytes (as specified by https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/io/File.html#length()). 
The use case I have it is where we have some report generation and we want to check that at least some file with some content was generated.

issue.title: Adding hasSize file assertion

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
#### Check List:
* Fixes #1311 (planning to raise one PR per assertion)
* Unit tests : YES
* Javadoc with a code example (on API only) : YES

body: I'm reviewing #1614 and I wonder if we should rename the assertion `hasSize` to `hasSizeInBytes` ? thoughts ?
I'd suppose `bytes` is implicit, so just having `hasSize` seems pretty clear (to me, at least)
